</ref> An example of a moral code is the Hebrew [[10 commandments]], a list of absolute rules regarding what god demands. The [[Golden Rule]] is however, not an example of a moral code, but a guideline that states that, "One should treat others as one would like others to treat oneself."<ref name = "Flew">{{Cite encyclopedia |title=golden rule|editor =[[Antony Flew]] | encyclopedia=A Dictionary of Philosophy | publisher = [[Pan Books]] in association with [[Macmillan Publishers|The MacMillan Press]] | year = 1979 | location = London | page = 134 | isbn = 9780333262047 }} This dictionary of philosophy contains the following exact quote under the entry for "golden rule": "The maxim 'Treat others how you wish to be treated'. Various expressions of this oft-cited moral rule are to be found in tenets of most religions and creeds through the ages, testifying to its universal applicability." (end quote)</ref> However, some have evaluated the Golden Rule as a rule of practicality.
    −
Simply believing that one is doing good for another because they are acting how they would like to be treated themselves, does not make it a moral act. This ignores the fact that personal likes/dislikes imposed on others is not a good deed if they are unwelcome. This "doing unto" may be an unwelcome imposition, when considering that some people may want to be left alone. Some people may want to left alone or have bizarre tastes. By not doing bad unto others, one decreases the possibility of undesirable consequences returned on them, such as retaliation, social ostracism. "Do unto others as you would have them do to you," when stated conversely, the message is "Do not do bad or misdeeds unto others in order to avoid retaliation." This is not a moral code, but a rule of self-interest. However, "love your neighbor as yourself" could be considered a moral guideline, but no more profound than "be kind" or "mean people suck."

"Do unto others as you would have them do to you," is the same as "do good to receive good." When stated conversely, the message is "Do not do bad or misdeeds unto others in order to avoid retaliation." This is not a moral code, but a rule of self-interest. However, "love your neighbor as yourself" could be considered a moral guideline, but no more profound than "be kind" or "mean people suck."
